summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing the handling of Touhy requests (requests for government information in third-party litigation) from victims of Jeffrey Epstein. It details internal coordination on drafting response letters, determining what documents to produce, and navigating jurisdictional issues with other U.S. Attorney's Offices.

persons.name: Steven Kochevar
persons.context: Primary point of contact for handling Touhy requests from Epstein victims; drafts and circulates response letters and coordinates document production.

persons.name: John McEnany
persons.context: Provides legal review and approval for Touhy request responses, raises concerns about Giglio disclosures and jurisdictional issues.

persons.name: David Jones
persons.context: Copied on email chain regarding Touhy request procedures and approvals.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: Involved in coordinating with the Civil Division on Touhy requests, particularly regarding communications with victim's counsel.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the investigative materials being requested through the Touhy process by victims.

persons.name: Maria Lacerda
persons.context: Identified as a Jane Doe victim who submitted a Touhy request for documents; mentioned in context of a grand jury subpoena.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney for victims/plaintiffs making Touhy requests; communications are directed to her firm, Kaplan Hecker.

persons.name: Sarah
persons.context: Mentioned as a 'wiser Touhy head' to be consulted on complex jurisdictional questions.

persons.name: Jeffrey O
persons.context: Mentioned as having approved Steven Kochevar continuing as the point of contact for Touhy requests.

persons.name: Rossmiller
persons.context: Mentioned in draft language as the initial recipient of a victim's request for information.

connections.description: Collaborate on drafting and approving legal responses to Touhy requests; McEnany reviews Kochevar's drafts.
Coordinate on handling victim requests, with Alex from the criminal side providing context and Kochevar from civil handling communications.
Both are AUSAs copied on internal emails discussing Touhy request strategies and approvals.
Kaplan is identified as counsel for victims like Lacerda who are making Touhy requests for Epstein-related documents.
Kochevar is the government point of contact sending formal Touhy response letters to Kaplan, who represents requesting victims.

events.title: Final Approval of Touhy Response Letter
events.description: Email chain confirms accuracy of qualifiers added to a draft letter responding to an Epstein victim's Touhy request.

events.title: Updated Letter to Epstein Victim
events.description: Kochevar circulates an updated Touhy response letter that the 'Maxwell team' has approved, following a call with McEnany.

events.title: Approval for Document Production to Maria Lacerda
events.description: McEnany approves producing documents, including a previously disclosed grand jury subpoena, to victim Maria Lacerda via the Touhy process.

events.title: Establishment of Touhy Request Process
events.description: Internal discussion establishes Steven Kochevar as the point person for handling Touhy requests from Epstein victims, with criminal AUSAs providing support.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) had an established internal process for handling Touhy requests from Jeffrey Epstein's victims for government documents.
A victim identified as Maria Lacerda made a Touhy request, and the office produced documents to her, including a grand jury subpoena that had been previously disclosed to her.
The office did not possess files from the U.S. Attorney's Office in the Southern District of Florida (SDFL) related to its Epstein investigation, citing conflict and discovery issues.
Internal emails reveal coordination with the 'Maxwell team' (presumably Ghislaine Maxwell's prosecution team) on approving responses to victim requests.
Prosecutors were aware that communications with victims (referred to as 'VB') via the Touhy process were likely disclosable as Giglio information (impeachment material).
